awd_titl_txt: NSF-DFG Echem: CAS: Synergistic Experimental and Computational Approaches to Designing Electrocatalysts with Proton-Responsive Ligand Architectures
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemical Catalysis program in the Division of Chemistry, Demyan Prokopchuk of Rutgers University-Newark will design electrocatalysts for generating chemical fuels. Storing and releasing electrical energy in the form of chemical bonds is attractive because of its scalability and flexibility for short or long term fuel deployment. Fundamental research into the sustainable production of energy-dense chemical fuels will be essential for an environmentally responsible energy future. To that end, this research program will develop biologically-inspired electrocatalysts using Earth-abundant metals. To accelerate electrocatalyst development, the program will focus on understanding reaction mechanisms by combining the unique expertise of experimental chemists at Rutgers in the US and theoretical chemists at the University of Bonn in Germany. Students from US and German institutions will participate in cross-border research exchanges. Partnering with a local glassblowing organization for underprivileged youth will engage Professor Prokopchuk with the community. Undergraduate participation will be integrated into these research efforts through minority scholarship programs, summer internship opportunities, and upper-level chemistry research projects. The project was awarded through the "NSF-DFG Lead Agency Activity in Electrosynthesis and Electrocatalysis (NSF-DFG EChem)" opportunity, a collaborative solicitation that involves NSF and Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG).

In partnership with collaborators at the University of Bonn in Germany,  Demyan Prokopchuk of Rutgers University-Newark will design earth-abundant metal-base electrocatalysts for chemical fuel generation. Enzymes have evolved in remarkable ways to efficiently and selectively activate small molecules under mild biological conditions using earth-abundant metals (EAMs) shrouded by enzymatic scaffolding. Thus, coaxing EAMs to catalyze reactions under abiotic conditions while replicating the activity and efficiency of their enzymatic relatives remains a challenge in the arena of fundamental science. This program will focus on designing synthetically tractable homogeneous EAM electrocatalysts with biologically-inspired amine functionalized ligands at Rutgers in the US and will be tightly coupled with computational datasets to guide laboratory efforts with collaborators at the University of Bonn in Germany. Synergistic cooperation between experimental and theoretical chemists will survey free energy landscapes by using state-of-the-art quantum chemical methods. Electrocatalyst performance will be assessed by understating reaction mechanisms and probing scaling relationships. Students from German and US institutions will participate in international research exchanges. Dr. Prokopchuk will engage with the community, including youth from underprivileged youth in  partnership with a local glassblowing organization. Undergraduate participation will be integrated into these research efforts through minority scholarship programs, summer internship opportunities, and upper-level chemistry research projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Storing and releasing electrical energy using small molecules such as hydrogen gas (H2) is attractive because of its scalability and flexibility for short-term or long-term fuel deployment. Fundamental research into the sustainable production of energy-dense chemical fuels will be essential for an environmentally responsible energy future, and this research developed biologically-inspired electrocatalysts using a cutting-edge blend of experimental and computational design. This joint USA-Germany research program combined the synthetic expertise of Dr. Prokopchuk (Rutgers-Newark) with Dr. Stefan Grimme (University of Bonn), an expert in computational workflows to improve catalyst performance via accurate energetic analysis. With this synergy in mind, Dr. Prokopchuk and his team prepared new organometallic compounds containing iron, manganese, and cobalt and explored their chemical properties. By combining protons and electrons in the presence of an iron-based electrocatalyst, an unexpected component of the catalyst framework served as a docking point for protons to produce hydrogen gas (H2) through a novel activation mechanism. Experimental and computational energy landscape analyses in each project were essential to rationalize reaction outcomes, understand elementary steps, and guide future synthetic campaigns. The products of this work include eight peer-reviewed publications one invited article, and one PhD dissertation.

Students and postdocs participating in the program gained hard skills by operating specialized research equipment and collecting spectroscopic data. Soft skills were molded by students presenting at group meetings and one-on-one research updates with Dr. Prokopchuk. Email exchanges and video meetings between computational partners in Germany and members of the Prokopchuk group occurred at all stages of project execution. The interdisciplinary nature of this program exposed students and postdocs to different areas of fundamental research and provided training in relation to sustainable chemistry. Reciprocal visits have been made by Prof. Grimme and Prof. Prokopchuk for departmental seminars. Dr. Grimme was co-hosted by Chemistry and Physics during his visit to Rutgers-Newark, stimulating multi-departmental research discussions. Dr. Prokopchuk introduced new modules into the advanced undergraduate curriculum for chemistry majors, which involved synthesis, flame sealing glass sample tubes, and organizing a field trip to a non-profit glassblowing studio to learn the basics of scientific glassblowing.

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2025
Modified by: Demyan E Prokopchuk
